content:
Both Bear and Notion offer free versions or trial periods, so you can try them out before committing to a paid plan.

**Bear**:

* Free version: Yes, Bear has a free version that allows you to create notes, use tags, and sync across all your devices. The free version has some limitations, such as a maximum of 150 notes and a 150,000 character limit per note.
* Trial period: None, but you can try out the free version indefinitely.
* Paid plan: Bear Pro, which offers additional features like advanced exporting, themes, and more, costs $1.49/month or $14.99/year.

**Notion**:

* Free version: Yes, Notion has a free plan that allows you to create up to 100 blocks (which can be notes, tasks, databases, or pages). The free plan also includes unlimited pages and blocks, but with some limitations on file uploads and version history.
* Trial period: None, but you can try out the free plan indefinitely.
* Paid plan: Notion Personal, which offers additional features like unlimited blocks, file uploads, and version history, costs $4/month or $40/year. They also have a Team plan for $8/user/month (billed annually).

Both Bear and Notion offer generous free versions or trials, so you can try them out without committing to a paid plan. This will give you a chance to see if you like their features, interface, and workflow.

Remember, it's essential to try out a few options to see which one fits your needs and workflow best. You might find that one of these apps becomes your new favorite tool for note-taking and organization!
